newsitem.title: USA: Kmart stock falls on worries about management turmoil.
newsitem.headline: Kmart stock falls on worries about management turmoil.

text.p: Kmart Corp.'s stock declined Thursday on worries that management turmoil would pressure earnings and postpone a turnaround in sales.

Several Wall Street analysts reduced estimates of Kmart's earnings for the second quarter after the retailer announced Wednesday that Stephen Ross, the head of apparel merchandise, had left the company.
Kmart's shares fell 25 cents to $12.75 in active trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

On Wednesday, Troy, Mich.-based Kmart said the departure of Ross was a mutual decision, and the retailer had launched a search for his replacement. Meanwhile, Warren Flick, president and chief operating officer of U.S. Kmart stores, was to oversee apparel merchandise management.
"It's good news and bad news," said Richard Church of Smith Barney. The good news is "they're holding people accountable." But the bad news, he said, is that KMart suffered because of the mistakes.
Kmart's apparel sales hit the brakes in the first quarter, and the company planned to slash prices on $100 million in unsold goods.
Analysts said the markdowns would hurt Kmart's earnings, and the upheaval in the management ranks could delay a rebound in sales.
Merrill Lynch analyst Daniel Barry cut his estimate for Kmart's second-quarter earnings by 2 cents to 8 cents a share. Last year, Kmart earned $34 million, or 7 cents a share, in the second quarter.
"It's easy to liquidate inventory," Church said. "It takes more time to create a team that's going to make changes in the store."
